questions.question: What is a direct proof?
questions.explanation: Method: assume given, step by step to result. Process: logical sequence. Example: prove n even implies 2n even. Application: most proofs. Importance: basic technique. Advantage: straightforward.

questions.question: What is proof by contradiction?
questions.explanation: Method: assume p, show contradiction, conclude p. Logic: pp ensures result. Example: 2 irrational. Application: many proofs. Advantage: sometimes simpler. Importance: fundamental.

questions.question: What is proof by contrapositive?
questions.explanation: Method: to prove pq, prove qp. Equivalence: both logically same. Example: if n even then n even. Application: alternative approach. Advantage: sometimes easier. Importance: technique.

questions.question: What is mathematical induction?
questions.answer: Proving base case and inductive step
questions.explanation: Method: base P(1) true, if P(n) then P(n+1). Purpose: all natural numbers. Example: sum formulas. Application: integers. Importance: essential. Power: infinite proof.

questions.question: What is the base case?
questions.explanation: Step: verify P(1) true. Purpose: induction foundation. Application: starting point. Importance: essential. Neglect: proof fails. Example: i=1 to n i = n(n+1)/2 true for n=1.

questions.question: What is the inductive step?
questions.explanation: Step: assume P(n), show P(n+1) follows. Assumption: inductive hypothesis. Purpose: propagation. Application: progression. Importance: essential. Logic: deduction rule.

questions.question: What is the inductive hypothesis?
questions.explanation: Hypothesis: assume P(n). Purpose: derive P(n+1). Role: critical. Application: reasoning. Importance: formal assumption. Logic: conditional.

questions.question: What is strong induction?
questions.explanation: Hypothesis: assume P(1)...P(n). Purpose: derive P(n+1). Advantage: uses more information. Application: needed for some proofs. Comparison: stronger than weak. Importance: variant.

questions.question: What is proof by cases?
questions.explanation: Method: partition into exhaustive cases. Step: prove each case. Conclusion: covers all. Example: |x| definition. Application: disjunctive premises. Importance: technique.

questions.question: What is a counterexample?
questions.explanation: Method: show premise true, conclusion false. Effect: disproves statement. Power: one sufficient. Example: not all primes odd (2). Application: disproving. Importance: technique.
